history.text: I really think that musicals are fun to watch.
So do I. Especially musicals that have a comedy aspect to them.
Do you think that Ryan Gosling is a good choice for the pianist role?
I think that romantic comedies are the best.
I believe so. He's charismatic and has a personality that makes him seem like he could pull of the pianist role.
Do you think Emma Stone is a good choice for being an inspiring actress?
I think she's the perfect choice but I didn't know she could sing.
Neither did I. Do you agree with the ratings of the movie?
I think that I do but I haven't seen the movie so it's hard to say.
Aren't we supposed to be moved on ????
I think so. Maybe after a certain number of responses. I think both Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone were good choices for a romantic movie. Don't you agree?
I do agree.  They seem to be a perfect couple for this movie.  I guess Gosling is a musician in reality but who knows?
Yeah. I'm not sure if he really fits jazz though. It doesn't seem like his genre.

I think the scene with him disregarding the setlist and brushing Mia off is appropriate for his personality as he seems like someone who would be a bit full of himself, not caring about the rules or what other people think.
Gosling's character seems to be trying to ignore the overtures of Mia and making himself "hard to get".
Yeah, I didn't see it that way at first.
I only know what I'm reading about it and it seems like he really takes his time warming up to her.

Yeah. I think it's a smart decision on the director's part though because the audience wants them to be together. Taking so long keeps them on their toes and makes them want to keep watching to see if they do end up together.
That sounds exactly right.  But now I see that they moved in together.
It seems like they started by portraying him as someone full of himself, then reveal his true character further in, like when he takes the gig to make Mia happy, even though he's not happy himself.
Yes, they both appear to have concern for each other.  He encouraged Mia to write the play and she's upset that he's not happy with his new gig.
It really shows how much they belong together.
I'm wondering how they ever get to be successful and happy about what they're doing.
She accuses him of abandoning his dreams but he did it for her.

I'm surprised that Mia's play turns out to be a disaster. She probably blames him since he encouraged her to do it in the first place, and that's probably a part of why she is unwilling to forgive him.
It probably bothered her quite a bit that he didn't show up for it.
Yeah, probably. This fight was a good idea to keep audiences wanting them together.
She had to move back home because she couldn't pay the theater back.
After her moving back home, you wonder if/how they'll get back together.
I know--I guess we'll find out in the next paragraph.
It doesn't appear to be an easy "happy ending".
I agree. So far, it seems like a couple of the critics are wrong about the movie. It doesn't seem like it's dull at all.
Although, I normally picture musicals being different. Normally the whole cast breaks into song and dance.
Yes. it seems as if there isn't too much of that.
Where is the 4th paragraph??

I
I don't see much of the comedy aspect either,
I'm not sure.*
No, I don't see very much to laugh about so far.
Not by these scenes at least.
this is getting frustrating.
The last one makes me wonder if Sebastian is going to chase after her or if they're going to run into each other again.
The finish conversation button is available--do you have it as well?
Yes. Does that mean we can exit? The top of the page does say it's the end of the document.
I guess we can finish--thank you for the back and forth.
